00062     //  ==================  List of known machines  =================
00063 
00064     enum MACHINE  {
00065       MACHINE_SGI       = 1,
00066       MACHINE_RS6000    = 2,
00067       MACHINE_ALLIANT   = 3,
00068       MACHINE_ARDENT    = 4,
00069       MACHINE_TITAN     = 5,
00070       MACHINE_STARDENT  = 6,
00071       MACHINE_CONVEX    = 7,
00072       MACHINE_ESV       = 8,
00073       MACHINE_HP9000    = 9,
00074       MACHINE_SOLBOURNE = 10,
00075       MACHINE_SOLARIS   = 11,
00076       MACHINE_ALPHA     = 12,
00077       MACHINE_VMS       = 13,
00078       MACHINE_MVS       = 14,
00079       MACHINE_F2C_G77   = 15,
00080       MACHINE_LINUX     = 16,
00081       MACHINE_UNKNOWN   = 100
00082     };
00083 
00084     //  =============  Identification of the machine  ===============
00085 
00086 // IBM Unix RS/6000
00087 #if defined(_AIX) || defined(___AIX)
00088 # define CALL_LIKE_HPUX 1
00089 
00090 // Alliant
00091 #elif defined(alliant)
00092 # define CALL_LIKE_SUN  1
00093 
00094 // Ardent, Stardent/Titan
00095 #elif defined(ardent)
00096 # define CALL_LIKE_STARDENT 1
00097 #elif defined(titan)
00098 # define CALL_LIKE_STARDENT 2
00099 #elif defined(stardent)
00100 # define CALL_LIKE_STARDENT 3
00101 
00102 // Convex
00103 #elif defined(__convex__) || defined(__convexc__)
00104 # define CALL_LIKE_SUN  2
00105 
00106 // Evans and Sutherland
00107 #elif defined(ESV)
00108 # define CALL_LIKE_SUN  3
00109 
00110 // Hewlett Packard 9000/750 (RISC) models
00111 #elif defined(__hpux)
00112 # define CALL_LIKE_HPUX 2
00113 
00114 // Silicon Graphics IRIX systems, Iris'es, Indigo's, Crimson's etc.
00115 #elif defined(__sgi) || defined(sgi)
00116 # define CALL_LIKE_SUN  4
00117 
00118 // Solbourne's are Sun clones.
00119 #elif defined(solbourne)
00120 # define CALL_LIKE_SUN  5
00121 
00122 // Solaris 1 and 2
00123 #elif defined(sun) || defined(__sun)
00124 # define CALL_LIKE_SUN  6
00125 
00126 //  DEC, OSF/1, Alpha and Ultrix
00127 #elif defined(ultrix) || defined(__OSF1__) || defined(__osf__)
00128 # define CALL_LIKE_SUN  7
00129 
00130 // VMS
00131 #elif defined(vms) || defined(__vms) || defined(__VMS)
00132 # define CALL_LIKE_VMS  1
00133 
00134 // MVS stands for Microsoft Visual Studio
00135 #elif defined(_MVS)
00136 # define CALL_LIKE_MVS  1
00137 
00138 #elif defined(F2C) || defined(G77)
00139 # define CALL_LIKE_SUN  8
00140 
00141 #elif defined(linux)
00142 # define CALL_LIKE_SUN  9
00143 
00144 #else
00145 //# error System type is not known -- see the Installation Guide
00146 # define CALL_LIKE_SUN  100
00147 
00148 #endif

00152 //  =================  Machine-dependent definitions  ==================
00153 
00154 #ifdef CALL_LIKE_STARDENT
00155     // StrPar is used in Ardent-like machines' fortran calls
00156     // for passing a string parameter
00157     DefineStructure(StrPar)
00158     struct StrPar  {
00159       pstr S;
00160       int  len;
00161       int  id;
00162     };
00163 #endif
00164 
00165 
00166 //
00167 //   Macro  FORTRAN_SUBR(NAME,name,p_send,p_struct,p_sflw)
00168 // makes function header statements that allow for linking with
00169 // programs written in FORTRAN.
00170 //
00171 //   Parameters:
00172 //
00173 //   NAME      name of the FORTRAN subroutine in capital letters
00174 //   name      name of the FORTRAN subroutine in small letters
00175 //   p_send    parameter list (in brackets) with string lengths
00176 //             attached to the end of it (see below)
00177 //   p_struct  parameter list (in brackets) with strings passed
00178 //             as complex parameters, or structures
00179 //   p_sflw    parameter list (in brackets) with string lengths
00180 //             following immediately the string parameters
00181 //             (see below)
00182 //
00183 //   All non-string parameters must be passed as pointers, in
00184 // the same order as they enter the FORTRAN call. Rules for
00185 // the string parameters are as follows.
00186 //
00187 //   1. All strings should be specified as of 'fpstr' type.
00188 //      The 'fpstr' type is defined below and depends on the
00189 //      platform:
00190 //
00191 //        a) whenever length of string is passed as a separate
00192 //           parameter ( CALL_LIKE_SUN, CALL_LIKE_HPUX,
00193 //           CALL_LIKE_MVS )  'fpstr' is identical to 'pstr'.
00194 //           You may choose arbitrary name for the string,
00195 //           but you MUST use the same name, appended with
00196 //           suffix '_len', for its length (see example below).
00197 //
00198 //        b) whenever string and its length are passed as
00199 //           complex parameter, 'fpstr' is identical to the
00200 //           pointer on the corresponding structure:
00201 //             CALL_LIKE_STARDENT :
00202 //                 'fpstr' is identical to 'PStrPar'
00203 //             CALL_LIKE_VMS      :
00204 //                 'fpstr' is identical to 'dsc$descriptor_s *'
00205 //
00206 //      With 'fpstr' type, two important macro definition come:
00207 //
00208 //        i)  FTN_STR(s)  - returns pointer to fortran-passed
00209 //                          string s. This pointer is always
00210 //                          of 'pstr' type
00211 //        ii) FTN_LEN(s)  - returns integer length of fortran-
00212 //                          passed string s. For this macro to
00213 //                          work properly with SUN- and MVS-like
00214 //                          machines, always use suffix '_len'
00215 //                          for the string length parameters as
00216 //                          described in a) above.
00217 //
00218 //   2. Three parameter lists, each enclosed in brackets, should
00219 //      be given. These lists retain the general order of
00220 //      parameters in the corresponding fortran call. Non-string
00221 //      parameters are passed as pointers. String parameters
00222 //      and their lengths are passed differently in different
00223 //      lists:
00224 //
00225 //       p_send    strings enter their place in the list as in
00226 //                 the corresponding FORTRAN call, having 'fpstr'
00227 //                 parameter type. Their lengths are appended as
00228 //                 'int' to the end of the list. They should
00229 //                 retain the order in which the strings appear
00230 //                 in the list.
00231 //
00232 //       p_struct strings enter their place in the list as in
00233 //                 the corresponding FORTRAN call, having 'fpstr'
00234 //                 parameter type.
00235 //
00236 //       p_sflw    strings enter their place in the list as in
00237 //                 the corresponding FORTRAN call, having 'fpstr'
00238 //                 type and being immediately followed by their
00239 //                 lengths as 'int' parameters.
00240 //
00241 //
00242 //
00243 // Example:
00244 //
00245 //   FORTRAN statement
00246 //
00247 //     subroutine  SomeSub ( k,s1,a,s2,m )
00248 //     integer       k,m
00249 //     real          a
00250 //     character*(*) s1,s2
00251 //
00252 //   is translated to
00253 //
00254 //     FORTRAN_SUBR ( SOMESUB, somesub,
00255 //       ( int * k, fpstr s1, float * a, fpstr s2, int * m,
00256 //         int s1_len, int s2_len ),
00257 //       ( int * k, fpstr s1, float * a, fpstr s2, int * m ),
00258 //       ( int * k, fpstr s1, int s1_len, float * a,
00259 //         fpstr s2, int s2_len, int * m ) )
00260 //
00261 //
00262 //   The macro should replace ordinary function header
00263 // statements to assure compatibility with FORTRAN links.
00264 // In header files, do not forget to add semicolumn:
00265 //
00266 //   FORTRAN_SUBR ( .... );
00267 //
00268 // while in source files use simply
00269 //
00270 //   FORTRAN_SUBR ( .... )  {
00271 //    <source body, operators>
00272 //   }
00273 //
00274 //
00275 //
00276 //   Macro  FORTRAN_CALL(NAME,name,p_send,p_struct,p_sflw)
00277 // calls function defined with macro FORTRAN_SUBR(...), from
00278 // a C/C++ application. Its parameters and their meaning are
00279 // exactly identical to those of FORTRAN_SUBR(...).
00280 // FORTRAN_CALL(...) should be followed by semicolon.
00281 //
00282 
00283 
00284 //  **** type of real numbers in the API functions
00285 //       comment or uncomment the proper string
00286 
00287     typedef  float      apireal;   // FORTRAN  real*4
00288 /*
00289     typedef  double     apireal;    // FORTRAN  real*8
00290 */
00291 
00292 
00293 #if defined(CALL_LIKE_SUN)
00294 
00295     typedef pstr fpstr;
00296 
00297 # define FTN_STR(s)  s
00298 # define FTN_LEN(s)  s##_len
00299 
00300 # define char_struct(s)           \
00301     mmdb::pstr  s;                      \
00302     int   s##_len;
00303 # define fill_char_struct(s,str)  \
00304     s  = str;                     \
00305     s##_len = strlen(str);
00306 
00307 # ifdef __cplusplus
00308 #   define FORTRAN_SUBR(NAME,name,p_sun,p_stardent,p_mvs) \
00309     extern "C" void name##_ p_sun
00310 # else
00311 #   define FORTRAN_SUBR(NAME,name,p_sun,p_stardent,p_mvs) \
00312     void name##_ p_sun
00313 # endif
00314

00316     extern "C" void name##_ p_sun
00317 
00318 # define FORTRAN_CALL(NAME,name,p_sun,p_stardent,p_mvs) \
00319     name##_ p_sun
00320 
00321 # elif defined(CALL_LIKE_HPUX)
00322 
00323     typedef pstr fpstr;

00329     pstr  s;             \
00330     int   s##_len;
00331 # define fill_char_struct(s,str)  \

00333     s##_len = strlen(str);

00337     extern "C" void name p_sun
00338 # else
00339 #   define FORTRAN_SUBR(NAME,name,p_sun,p_stardent,p_mvs) \
00340     void name p_sun

00350 
00351     typedef PStrPar fpstr;
00352 
00353 # define FTN_STR(s)  s->S
00354 # define FTN_LEN(s)  s->len
00355 
00356 # define char_struct(s)           \
00357     StrPar s;
00358 # define fill_char_struct(s,str)  \
00359     s.S   = str;                  \
00360     s.len = strlen(FName);        \
00361     s.id  = 0;
00362 
00363 # ifdef __cplusplus
00364 #   define FORTRAN_SUBR(NAME,name,p_send,p_struct,p_sflw) \
00365     extern "C" void NAME p_stardent
00366 # else
00367 #   define FORTRAN_SUBR(NAME,name,p_send,p_struct,p_sflw) \
00368     void NAME p_stardent
00369 # endif
00370 
00371 # define FORTRAN_EXTERN(NAME,name,p_sun,p_stardent,p_mvs) \
00372     extern "C" void NAME p_stardent
00373 
00374 # define FORTRAN_CALL(NAME,name,p_send,p_struct,p_sflw) \
00375     NAME p_stardent
00376 
00377 #elif defined(CALL_LIKE_VMS)
00378 
00379     typedef dsc$descriptor_s * fpstr;
00380 
00381 # define FTN_STR(s)  s->dsc$a_pointer;
00382 # define FTN_LEN(s)  s->dsc$w_length;
00383 
00384 # define character(s)                \
00385     dsc$descriptor_s s;
00386 # define fill_char_struct(s,str)     \
00387     s.dsc$a_pointer = str;           \
00388     s.dsc$w_length  = strlen(str);   \
00389     s.dsc$b_dtype   = DSC$K_DTYPE_T; \
00390     s.dsc$b_class   = DSC$K_CLASS_S;
